div1.head: Analysis of history The most likely single cause of the presentation, other possible causes and reasons for these choices. The findings to be looked for on physical examination to help decide the cause.

p.s: Malignant melanoma of either of the following two types.
Nodular malignant melanoma - most aggressive type.
Presents as a rapidly growing pigmented nodule which bleeds or ulcerates.
Rarely are non-pigmented/amelanotic and can mimic pyogenic granuloma.
Superficial spreading malignant melanoma - a flat, irregularly pigmented lesion, large in size.
Grows laterally before vertical invasion develops.
Benign naevus
The following clinical criteria are an aid in distinguishing between the above differential diagnoses.
The Glasgow 7-point checklist
To support the most likely presenting diagnosis of malignant melanoma presents with all 3 of the major criteria in the Glasgow 7-point checklist, his mole has changed in size, shape and colour.
Of the minor criteria, his mole measures more than 6mm and it bleeds spontaneously on regular occasions.

History of sun exposure in childhood and intermittent exposure in adulthood are particularly important aetiological factors in the development of malignant melanoma. had been severely sunburnt in his childhood across his back and shoulder blades.
Other predisposing factors include atypical mole syndrome, giant congenital melanocytic naevi, lentigo maligna and positive family history of malignant melanoma.
Malignant melanoma is commoner in later life but can affect younger individuals.
Incidence is continuing to increase due to excessive exposure to sunlight.

p.s: Transitional cell tumours account for about 3% of deaths from all causes of malignancy.

Painless, frank haematuria is commonly the presenting symptom of bladder cancer and is an 'alarm' symptom warranting an urgent 2 week referral from a primary care setting (GP) to secondary care (hospital) for further investigation. fast-tracked this process by self-presenting straight to secondary care.
A diagnosis of bladder cancer is made by cystoscopy and should cancer be found regular cystoscopic screening is advised to monitor future occurrence of neoplastic growth.

Clearly the earlier the diagnosis, the sooner treatment can be started and the better the prognosis for the patient. presented with an 'alarm' symptom of cancer and although was found not to have this it was crucial he received treatment investigative of such.
The prognosis of bladder cancer ranges from a 5-year survival of 80-90% for lesions not involving bladder muscle to 5% for those invasive cancers with metastatic spread.
Patients from a stable family background and with social support respond best to treatment.
His family could contribute towards care and as such should be involved in his treatment and diagnosis. 's health needs to be optimised to enable him to maximise independence and quality of life.
